results.title: Begonia festival
results.creator_credit: David Corke, State Film Centre of Victoria and Boolari Films
results.brief_description: At the annual Begonia Festival, Ballarat becomes a city of flowers, music, dancing and drama centred on the famous begonia display. Mr. Tom Beaumont, the curator of the glass house in the Botanic Gardens, tends the many blooms. He is a world authority on begonia culture. Highlights of the display are a thousand double blooms and six hundred distinctive single varieties. In the gardens we see a fine display of salvias, gladioli and dahlias. Young and old admire the wonderful colour and variety of the Botanic Gardens and also the open air art exhibition. Commentary by John Morgan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, State Film Centre of Victoria and Boolari Films

results.title: Alpine Playground
results.creator_credit: Tourist Development Authority of Victoria and Cinesound
results.brief_description: A holiday with a difference; the joys of an alpine winter holiday in Victoria’s picturesque skiing resorts, Mt Buffalo, Mt Hotham and Falls Creek. Within easy reach of Melbourne, facilities include expert ski instruction, readily available ski tows, toboggans, and comfortable accommodation.

results.title: Going, going, still here!
results.creator_credit: Garry Hammer, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Garry Hammer and his family battle the Gippsland bushfires to save their home.
Garry’s story is a personal account of the fire front that swept through his property, creating its own weather, a life-threatening yet positive force that ultimately gave him a new perspective on his life and his relationship with his son.
This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Arts Victoria and Latrobe City.

results.title: The Burning question
results.creator_credit: David Guy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
When David moved from the city, he fulfilled a lifetime dream to live in a place he had always visited and dreamed of owning. Losing almost all of his property, he is faced with a burning question in this first-hand account of the devastating Gippsland bushfires.
This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Arts Victoria and Latrobe City.

results.title: BIT Plane
results.brief_description:
The Bitplane video captures an aero-portrait of a richly mythologised territory - the Silicon Valley in California, home to the largest concentration of wealth in California since the Gold Rush. The Bitplane’s mission takes it deep into the heart of the Valley, to view the source and progress of the Information Age. Due to its tiny dimensions, the Bitplane is able to enter territory inaccessible to other aircraft.

One of the issues the Bitplane engages with on this reconnaissance flight is the threat of the camera to information space. Cameras are not permitted into the corporate research parks in teh Valley, according to the logic that visitors could steal intellectual property by taking photographs. This reveals an assumption that information is something you can photograph, a thing - not the product of a community or expertise or a social network of shared discourse but something you could steal with a camera.

From the Artist Statement provided for PROOF exhibition, Dec 2004.

results.title: How to make a movie
results.brief_description: Although short and largely created to practise the Straford Brothers’ unique approach to editing and transitions, this already shows their ambitions for scene and story. Here, a frustrated filmmaker tries to make a ‘classic.’
